awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Self-Heating, Electrically Conductive Concrete Heated Pavement System for Sustainable Winter Maintenance Operation
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a sustainable heated pavement technology to melt ice and snow on paved surfaces during the winter season. Aviation and transportation agencies allocate significant time and resources each year to remove ice and snow from their paved surfaces to achieve a safe, accessible, and operational transportation network. Transportation networks experience a significant reduction in mobilization capacity due to speed reduction, delays, and in some cases complete shutdown of parts of the network due to snow and ice storms each winter.  The current practice for winter maintenance operation includes using snowplows and deicing chemicals, which is time-consuming, labor-intensive, and environmentally unfriendly. Implementation of the proposed technology may improve public safety, limit the use of salt and deicing chemicals, reduce delays and cancelations in the transportation system (airports, highways, etc.), reduce the slip and fall potential and the associated settlements. In addition, the proposed technology may ease the commute of individuals with disabilities in the winter season and better meet the Americans with Disabilities Act standards.  The technology is designed to be operated remotely via the internet, which further opens opportunities worldwide.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of an electrically conductive concrete (ECON) heated pavement system as an alternative to conventional snow and ice removal.  The proposed technology utilizes the inherent electrical resistance of concrete to electricity flow to generate heat, maintain the pavement surface above freezing temperatures, and thus prevent snow and ice accumulation on the surface. The electricity is applied using stainless steel rebars embedded in the ECON. A fully automated control system operates the system.  The testing and performance monitoring of this technology is in progress at two full-scale demonstration projects at Des Moines International Airport and the Iowa Department of Transportation headquarters. The proposed technology may provide a smart, environmentally friendly alternative to plowing and deicing operations and may effectively mitigate snow and ice formation on paved surfaces while enhancing the sustainability and resiliency of the infrastructure network in the winter season.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The proposed technology has many applications in different areas explained in detail as below:

·        Businesses and Municipalities 

One of the best applications of heated pavement areas is locations with high foot traffic and high geometric complexity. Downtown areas, due to high population is one beneficiary of implementing this technology due to both high pedestrian traffic and high geometric complexity. Higher foot traffic increases the chance of slip and fall in the winter season. Slip and fall lawsuits and the associated settlements can be mitigated by treating the most prone areas with heated pavement technology. In addition, it is more time-consuming for businesses and municipalities to clear the snow and ice in places where pedestrians are constantly walking, especially with high geometric design complexity (availability of obstacles). Based on the US Bureau of labor and statistics, there were 25,370 ice, sleet, and snow-related injuries in 2019 (US Bureau of labor and statistics 2019).

 

·        Airports 

Airport pavement snow removal and runway de-icing operations are expensive components of airport operational costs, and these operations can occasionally lead to flight delays impacting travel throughout the US and worldwide. The estimated cost per minute of delay in 2019 in US Airport was about $74 (Airlines For America 2019). The airport authorities can minimize the delay and maximize their enplanement and deplanement, which will result in increased revenue and operation in the winter season for airports.

 

·        Highways and Roadways

Potential locations for implementation of ECON HPS in highway and roadway systems include high traffic volume locations, rest areas, bridges, and ramps.

-        High traffic volume locations:

There are some critical locations in highway and roadway systems that affect the free flow of traffic in the whole system. Typically, these locations experience high traffic flow, and an accident in these locations due to the winter season can result in massive delays throughout the system.

-        Rest areas:

Rest areas specifically in interstate highway systems experience high foot traffic throughout the year, and they are typically located in areas that would not be easily accessible to the winter maintenance crew to clear the snow and ice in a timely manner.

-        Bridges:

Bridges are the first locations in the highway system to freeze during the beginning of the winter season. Black ice and frost create a thin layer of ice on top of the bridge deck, which may result in vehicles sliding off from the bridge and causing a fatal accident. Department of transportation dedicates portions of their winter maintenance budget for de-icing these locations (so-called frost run) for mitigating this hazard.

-        Ramps:

The entrance and exit ramps in the highway system are a potential hazard, specifically in the winter season due to vehicle higher speed and the potential of sliding off the ramp.

 

·        Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA)

ECON HPS technology is in full compliance with ADA's mission to ease the commute of individuals with disabilities, especially in the winter season. Based on the US Bureau of labor and statistics, about 25 percent of ice- and snow-related falls occur in parking lots. Snow and ice can cause significant hardship for individuals with disabilities, and implementing heated pavement on ADA parking lots and ramps can be a way to mitigate this hardship. In addition, the department of transportation has dedicated funding for ADA compliance projects that can be used to further implement ECON HPS, by facilitating the contribution of people with disabilities to our society.
